Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: CMOS-Compatible Oxide Films for Tunable Microwave Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce the cost of RF hardware, enabling wider adoption of new generations of mobile devices and services for Internet of Things applications. The project has the potential to help transform a number of sectors, including medicine and healthcare monitoring and diagnostics, transportation safety and infrastructure, air and water quality monitoring, and disaster warning and recovery efforts, particularly where wired infrastructure is inadequate or non-existent. The project will potentially remove design constraints for hardware developers seeking to directly incorporate RF tunability within their products.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses a persistent materials selection and processing challenge. Currently available families of functional materials typically require high-temperature processing and cannot be incorporated directly within the manufacturing of electronic devices for mobile communications, preventing facile and highly efficient tuning of frequencies. In this project, well-integrated multi-scale materials design, simulation, film growth, scalable processing and properties measurements will be employed to produce and optimize the performance of new tunable dielectric materials. The project will result in high-performance, manufacturing process-compatible tunable devices incorporating a new dielectric film material obtained through a much lower-temperature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complexity of communications systems and sub-systems in multi-band device electronics has increased in the last decade to meet the staggering growth in mobile data traffic, which is expected to increase tenfold by 2019 compared with 2014, reaching 25 billion gigabytes per month, through more than 11.5 billion mobile devices. The global fragmentation of spectrum assignments for Long-Term Evolution (LTE) added product complexity to infrastructure and mobile devices. This will continue as 5G is introduced, creating a great demand for product simplification in the radio-frequency (RF) front end. For example, the number of frequency bands to be covered in modern mobile phones is expected to escalate, as well as the number of filters for each frequency. Significant advances have been made in the manufacturing and performance of RF front end components.  However, the current wireless architecture relies principally on devices that are switches, i.e. essentially fixed in terms of frequency.  By decreasing the number of components, highly tunable frequency devices are natural candidates to simplify the RF architecture. Progress in improving mobile features has necessitated compromises in design and performance of the antenna, resulting in reduced data transmission rates, dropped calls, and inefficiencies in power consumption, posing challenges to handset manufacturers and network carriers alike. Power management over the operating frequency range in mobile and Internet of Things devices will be critical as it appeals directly to consumer need for a longer lasting battery.

These challenges set the stage for the investigation of new materials and processes with potential for enabling simplification in architecture. The team investigated the synthesis, processing and properties of active oxide films, including those produced using lower temperature methods, revealing how superlattice growth of film components followed by post-growth annealing enables formation phase-pure films with high control of elemental composition that exhibiting desired functional properties.  An approach integrating theory and materials design, simulation, properties prediction, film synthesis, characterization and testing was pursued. The team designed, modeled and prototyped candidate material properties to rapidly assess their technological promise, producing advanced dielectric materials predicting outstanding figures of merit based on theoretical model predictions.  The team characterized the structure and composition of the film, obtained film properties, produced and tested devices consistent with predictions, thereby validating models for creation of highly tunable and low-loss dielectric materials that are promising for commercial application. Graduate students participated and received mentoring in a collaborative project team environment. The broader impact of this Phase I project is that the technology under development has the potential to lower the bill of materials, and to enable higher data throughput and better wireless connections for the network carrier, and better battery life and user experience for the mobile customer. 


Last Modified: 03/06/2017
Modified by: Christopher R Elsass
